tree.mainmatter:
A strict 0-category is a set.
A strict (n+1)-category is a category enriched over nCat, the category of all strict n-categories.For the definition to make sense, it must hold that nCat is monoidal;

mainmatter.p: Let (K, \otimes , 1_ \otimes , \alpha , \lambda , \rho ) be a monoidal category. A category enriched over K (also called a K-category), C, consists of:

ul.li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y in C, an object C(x, y) of K;
for each object x in C, a designated identity morphism 1_ \otimes \xrightarrow{1_x} C(x, x);
for each triple of objects x,y,z in C, a designated composite morphism C(y,z) \otimes C(x,y) \xrightarrow{\circ _{x,y,z}} C(x,z).

mainmatter.p: This data must satisfy the associative and unit laws:
A monoidal structure on a category K consists of the following data:

ul.li: a bifunctor \otimes : K \times K \rightarrow K called the tensor product;
an object 1_ \otimes \in K called the tensor unit;

mainmatter.p: This data must satisfy the triangle and pentagon identities:
A category C consists of the following data:

ul.li: a collection of objects, overloadingly also called C;
for each pair of objects x,y \in C, a collection of morphisms #C(x, y);
for each object x \in C, a designated identity morphism x \xrightarrow{1_x} x;
for each pair of morphisms x \xrightarrow{f} y \xrightarrow{g} z, a designated composite morphism x \xrightarrow{gf} z.

mainmatter.p: This data must satisfy the following axioms:

ul.li: unitality: for any x \xrightarrow{f} y, 1_yf = f = f1_x;
associativity: for any x \xrightarrow{f} y \xrightarrow{g} z \xrightarrow{h} w, (hg)f = h(gf).

mainmatter.p: In other words, the following diagrams must commute:
